items.title: How work with composite id in Table.Join?
items.body:
Hello,
I'm trying to use a composite id in Table.Join, 
I'm pass the both key in left and right sides, 

```
jointab = tables[0]
testea = [3,5]
testeb = [8,1]
jointab = agate.Table.join(jointab, table, testea, testeb)
```

And i'm gotting this error

> tuple.index(x): x not in tuple

Has an way to work with composite id?
Thanks.

items.title: Is it possible to pass variables to an Agate.Formula()?
items.body:
As far as I can tell, there's no way to pass a variable to a custom Agate.Formula(), right? 

I know I can do this, and `x_y_to_lat_lng()` will receive a `row` variable:
```
    new_table = new_table.compute([
        ('coordinates', agate.Formula( text_type, x_y_to_lat_lng )),
    ])
```

But is there a way to do the equivalent of something like this?

```
    new_table = new_table.compute([
        ('coordinates', agate.Formula( text_type, x_y_to_lat_lng(geojson) )),
    ])
```

I'd like to load a file once and pass its data to the `x_y_to_lat_lng()` function. But all I can figure out how to do is to load the file _within_ the function, which means loading it thousands of times as I process all the rows in a table.

You may want to [change the link.](https://github.com/wireservice/agate/blob/master/example.py.ipynb)

items.title: make_number_formatter() causing UnicodeDecodeError on FreeBSD
items.body:
I have some code that I run under Python 2.7.15 in two different environments: Mac OS X and FreeBSD.

(I'm using Agate 1.6.1 and csvkit 1.0.3 in both environments)

The trouble is using `.print_table()` on columns with long decimals. It's working fine on my Mac, but when I run the same code under FreeBSD, I get errors like this:

```
  File "csv_to_json.py", line 89, in read_incident_csv
    incident_table.print_table( max_columns=15, max_column_width=6, output=output_device )
  File "/home/newsroom/.virtualenvs/crime/lib/python2.7/site-packages/agate/table/print_table.py", line 156, in print_table
    write_row(formatted_row)
  File "/home/newsroom/.virtualenvs/crime/lib/python2.7/site-packages/agate/table/print_table.py", line 140, in write_row
    write('%s%s%s' % (v_line, text, v_line))
  File "/home/newsroom/.virtualenvs/crime/lib/python2.7/site-packages/agate/table/print_table.py", line 121, in write
    output.write(line + '\n')
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u2026' in position 67: ordinal not in range(128)
```

The issue seems to be an ellipsis character which is added to my lat/lng columns (which are very long decimals) by [this line](https://github.com/wireservice/agate/blob/master/agate/utils.py#L169) in `make_number_formatter()`:

```
    ellipsis = u'…' if add_ellipsis else u''
```

If I edit `utils.py` and change that Unicode ellipsis to be some other simple ASCII character, like an exclamation mark, then `print_table()` works fine in my FreeBSD environment.

I don't really understand why this is going wrong. Maybe there's something I could do in my environment to avoid it? FWIW, I checked the locales in each environment, and FreeBSD reports the same values as my Mac:

```
LANG=
LC_CTYPE="C"
LC_COLLATE="C"
LC_TIME="C"
LC_NUMERIC="C"
LC_MONETARY="C"
LC_MESSAGES="C"
LC_ALL=
```

On a whim, I tried passing a locale value of `en-US.UTF-8` to `print_table()`, but it didn't make any difference.

However, I want to point out that it seems weird to have this hard-coded ellipsis character in the `make_number_formatter()` function, particularly when you [provide a place to specify custom ellipsis characters](https://github.com/wireservice/agate/blob/master/agate/config.py#L56) in `config.py`. Shouldn't `make_number_formatter()` use that value instead?

items.title: TypeError when re.match hits null

`re.match('^TEMPORARY (?!SPACE)', row['PURPOSE']))`

items.title: Having problems with having
items.body:
See code snippet below.  I'm getting KeyError when trying to using having clause below:

```
        by_building = table.group_by('BuildingID')
        by_building_by_date = by_building.group_by('EffectiveDate')

        # DEBUG: Doesn't work below?!
        by_building_by_date_having_multiple = by_building_by_date.having([
            ('count', agate.Count()),
            ], lambda aggregations: aggregations['count'] > 1)   # KeyError here
        by_building_by_date_having_multiple.print_table()
```

Debugging the code, it seems Agate's having implementation is using a list of tuples.  I was expecting it to behave like a dictionary.  Or maybe I'm doing something completely wrong?

items.title: BOM question
items.body:
Hello!

I am working on a [small Python library](https://github.com/datadesk/python-censusbatchgeocoder) that uses agate's handy csv reader and writer methods internally to handle data files. I've run into an edge case and I wonder if you can help me with it.

It has to do with our old buddy, the Windows BOM. Sometimes, files will start with it and then ``\ufeff`` will appear on the first header's key when using ``agate.csv.DictReader``. 

The unicodecsv library appear to handle this issue if you do something like this:

```python
unicodecsv.DictReader(open("./data.csv", 'r'), encoding="utf-8-sig")
```

Does agate offer some similar solution, or something else I can do or offer to my module's users to help them work through this kind of thing?

items.title: "last week" often causes datetime inference issue
items.body:
I was attempting to use [csvkit](https://github.com/wireservice/csvkit)'s `csvlook` to view a CSV of template-generated text, and it kept failing with the error `date value out of range`.

Based on the guidance from wireservice/csvkit#822, I passed `--no-inference` and all was well, but I tried to narrow down the problem.

It turns out the phrase `last week` in a cell can cause it to be inferred as a datetime (similar to #653) _and_ raise an exception while doing so. `this week` and `next week` also get inferred as datetimes, but they at least don't raise anything when they do.

Here's the bare minimum example from `csvlook`:

```
$ echo "snippet
last week" | csvlook
date value out of range

$ echo "snippet
last week" | csvlook --no-inference
| snippet   |
| --------- |
| last week |

$ echo "snippet
this week" | csvlook
|    snippet |
| ---------- |
| 0001-01-05 |

$ echo "snippet
next week" | csvlook
|    snippet |
| ---------- |
| 0001-01-08 |
```

Here's the agate-specific demo, based on the fix from #653:

```
>>> agate.Date().cast('next week')
datetime.date(1, 1, 8)
>>> agate.Date().cast('this week')
datetime.date(1, 1, 5)
>>> agate.Date().cast('last week')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/idguser/.virtualenvs/tmp-b84b060a7955a57d/lib/python3.5/site-packages/agate/data_types/date.py", line 75, in cast
    value, ctx = self.parser.parseDT(d, sourceTime=ZERO_DT)
  File "/Users/idguser/.virtualenvs/tmp-b84b060a7955a57d/lib/python3.5/site-packages/parsedatetime/__init__.py", line 1771, in parseDT
    version=version)
  File "/Users/idguser/.virtualenvs/tmp-b84b060a7955a57d/lib/python3.5/site-packages/parsedatetime/__init__.py", line 1845, in parse
    retS, retTime, matched = parseMeth(s, sourceTime)
  File "/Users/idguser/.virtualenvs/tmp-b84b060a7955a57d/lib/python3.5/site-packages/parsedatetime/__init__.py", line 1316, in _partialParseModifier
    chunk2, sourceTime)
  File "/Users/idguser/.virtualenvs/tmp-b84b060a7955a57d/lib/python3.5/site-packages/parsedatetime/__init__.py", line 848, in _evalModifier
    target = start + offset * datetime.timedelta(weeks=1)
OverflowError: date value out of range
```

The inference sometimes can persist even when the `$WORD week` phrase has other stuff around it (which is how I found this), but not always:

```
$ echo "snippet
I had lunch last week." | csvlook
| snippet                |
| ---------------------- |
| I had lunch last week. |

$ echo "snippet
I had lunch last week," | csvlook
date value out of range
```

items.title: GPLv3 dependency
items.body:
Hi,

In order to update [csvkit](https://github.com/wireservice/csvkit) to 1.0.1 in fedora, I am in the process of packaging agate. During this process, I found that it relies on a GPLv3 dependency [awesome-slugify](https://github.com/dimka665/awesome-slugify) (cf [awesome-slugify](https://github.com/dimka665/awesome-slugify/blob/master/setup.py#L22)) while being licensed on the MIT license.

As far a I know, this means that agate needs to be license under GPLv3.

Possible solutions:
- Switch to another lib to create slug.  Eg [python-slugify](https://github.com/un33k/python-slugify) (doesn't support unique slugs though)
- Make awesome-slugify change their license. There is an on going discussion about this [here](https://github.com/dimka665/awesome-slugify/issues/24). It is currently released under GPLv3 because one of its dependencies is GPLv2+. Some are asking the maintainer to switch to something else.

items.title: Is utf-8 hardcoded?
items.body:
$ ./test.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./test.py", line 34, in <module>
    main()
  File "./test.py", line 18, in main
    lineitems = agate.Table.from_csv('in.csv')
  File "C:\Users\Tim\Anaconda2\lib\site-packages\agate\table\from_csv.py", line 69, in from_csv
    f = six.StringIO(f.read().encode('utf-8'))
  File "C:\Users\Tim\Anaconda2\lib\codecs.py", line 314, in decode
    (result, consumed) = self._buffer_decode(data, self.errors, final)
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf8' codec can't decode byte 0xfc in position 569372: invalid start byte

Is there a way of using the system encoding (which I can set to iso-8859-1) or let us pass it in to the reader?

This is pretty essential to usability on Windows are we're going to get a variety of encodings on csv files - and it's a bit of barrier to entry if you get arcane failures at the first step.

in the [SQL cookbook](http://agate.readthedocs.io/en/1.4.0/cookbook/sql.html) portion the following: 
new_table = table.select(('state', 'total'))

should have inner brackets instead of two parens (same for the Chain commands together section on that page)

new_table = table.select(['state', 'total'])

items.title: Clarify vlookup by join documentation
items.body:
The documentation under "[vlookup](http://agate.readthedocs.io/en/1.4.0/cookbook/excel.html#vlookup)" says that join will add the columns from the passed table to the table on which join is operating. From this description, I expect the number of rows of the resulting table to be the same as the table on which join is operating. Changing the position of the tables doesn't result in differences in the end table row length for me (meaning that I end up with many duplicate rows).

![screen shot 2016-07-06 at 5 01 46 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3254939/16634462/d35d9004-439b-11e6-93d7-a585b7aa0e51.png)

items.title: Can't group_by Boolean datatypes
items.body:
If I run this:

``` python
import agate

rows = [
    dict(bool=True, number=1),
    dict(bool=True, number=1),
    dict(bool=False, number=1)
]
column_types = (agate.Boolean(), agate.Number())
table = agate.Table.from_object(rows, column_types=column_types)

table = table.group_by("bool").aggregate([
    ('sum', agate.Sum('number'))
])
table.print_table()
```

I get this error:

``` python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "scratch.py", line 12, in <module>
    ('sum', agate.Sum('number'))
  File "/home/ben/Code/agate/agate/tableset/aggregate.py", line 81, in aggregate
    return Table(output, column_names, column_types, row_names=row_names)
  File "/home/ben/Code/agate/agate/table/__init__.py", line 180, in __init__
    raise ValueError('Row names cannot be of type int. Use Decimal for numbered row names.')
ValueError: Row names cannot be of type int. Use Decimal for numbered row names.
```

But I change the data type of the first column to `Text` it works.

``` python
import agate

rows = [
    dict(bool=True, number=1),
    dict(bool=True, number=1),
    dict(bool=False, number=1)
]
column_types = (agate.Text(), agate.Number())
table = agate.Table.from_object(rows, column_types=column_types)

table = table.group_by("bool").aggregate([
    ('sum', agate.Sum('number'))
])
table.print_table()
```

``` bash
|--------+------|
|  bool  | sum  |
|--------+------|
|  True  |   2  |
|  False |   1  |
|--------+------|
```

That seems wrong to me. My gut says users should be able to group by boolean columns just as they do text columns.

items.title: Flag for rendering Markdown-friendly tables?
items.body:
Not sure if this is a feature that would be useful to many. There have been a few occasions where I'd like the output of csvlook to be a Multi-Markdown table. It's very close to being compatible as it is.

Here are the changes I just made to a very simple table to change from csvlook output to make a Markdown-friendly table:
- Remove top and bottom "frame" rows (the pipe, dashes and plus signs on the first and last line).
- Remove pipes at beginning and end of lines
- Change plus signs in separator rows to pipes

_[previously suggested over on csvkit](https://github.com/wireservice/csvkit/issues/620), @jpmckinney said it's rendered from here_

items.title: Cookbook: standardize column values with Slugify computation
Cookbook: slugify/standardize row and column names
Can't run compute on a joined table because rows are constructed as lists instead of tuples
Document configuration system
items.body: See `agate/config.py`

items.title: TypeError: 'TypeTester' object is not iterable
items.body:
I'm trying to get the [tutorial](http://agate.readthedocs.io/en/1.3.1/tutorial.html) to work on my laptop (Ubuntu 14.04 and Python 2.7.6) and hitting an error early on that I can't seem to debug. I haven't been able to find another example of this issue.

Here's what I've got in a file called `agate_test.py`, referencing the example CSV from the tutorial.

```
import agate

tester = agate.TypeTester(limit=100)

exonerations = agate.Table.from_csv('exonerations-20150828.csv', tester)
```

Then I run the command `python agate_test.py` and get this message:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "agate_test.py", line 5, in <module>
    exonerations = agate.Table.from_csv('exonerations-20150828.csv', tester)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/agate/table/__init__.py", line 372, in from_csv
    return Table(rows, column_names, column_types, row_names=row_names)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/agate/table/__init__.py", line 102, in __init__
    for i, column_name in enumerate(column_names):
TypeError: 'TypeTester' object is not iterable
```

I get the same problem with other CSV files as well.

items.title: print_table max_column_width does not restrict column names
Rewrite the agate tutorial as a Jupyter notebook
items.body: After seeing [this](http://buzzfeednews.github.io/2016-04-federal-surveillance-planes/analysis.html) today it seems obvious to me now that the agate tutorial should simply be a Jupyter notebook. In addition to being more readable, it'll also benefit from being easier to test/sync when we change things and it pushes people in the direction of tools they should probably be using anyway.

items.title: Cookbook: Top N percent
items.body:
Under the [filter](https://agate.readthedocs.org/en/1.3.1/cookbook/filter.html) section, in the section N percent, is the following code:

```
percentiles = table.aggregate(agate.Percentiles('salary'])
top_ten_percent = table.where(lambda r: r['salary'] >= percentiles[90])
```

There is a typo where it is missing a bracket in the first line.

Additionally, the code results in the following error: 

'type' object is not subscriptable

You can see that with the following: 

```
rows = [
    dict(letter='a', number=1),
    dict(letter='b', number=2),
    dict(letter='c', number=3),
    dict(letter='c', number=4),
    dict(letter='c', number=5)
]

table = agate.Table.from_object(rows)
percentiles = table.aggregate(agate.Percentiles['number'])
top_ten_percent = table.where(lambda r: r['number'] >= percentiles[90])

```

Assuming this is a documentation problem...

items.title: Results of profiling table creation
items.body:
Since there has been some concern about data size limits, I thought I would do a little profiling. This isn't a TODO, I just wanted these notes to be somewhere where they could easily be discussed.

For these tests I used the MOMA artworks dataset. The version I have locally is a 36.2 MB CSV. It has 126,118 and 14 columns. The TypeTester infers this dataset to have 1 Boolean column Boolean, 1 Number, 1 Date, and 11 Text.

With cProfile running, loading this dataset takes:
- 90.0s with no args
- 42.0s with `limit=100`
- 39.8s with all columns manually typed (to the same types TypeTester would infer)
- 26.5s with `types=[agate.Boolean(), agate.Number(), agate.Text()`
- 6.6s with all columns manually typed to `Text()`

(These were all single tests, so useful as order-of-magnitude measures only.)

What this tells me is that the single slowest part of the process is type testing—especially testing dates. Date/time testing is abominably slow, which isn't surprising. Number casting (via [babel](http://babel.pocoo.org/en/latest/)) is also slower than I would like.

items.title: Switch to column-oriented data storage
items.body: I've been thinking a lot about this and I think it can be a huge performance win. Should be relatively straightforward given how abstracted the row/column internals are now.

items.title: Table.bins ignores start or end input if only one is specified
Cookbook: computing a new sequence of columns
items.body: Show how to use a for loop to create a list of (name, computation) tuples suitable for computing a derived sequence. (E.g. year columns to year_pct_change columns.)

items.title: Table.compute(replace=True)
items.body:
I constantly find myself wanting to compute a variation of a column in-place, especially for data-cleaning. We should add a "replace" flag that allows new column names to be the names of existing columns. They will be replaced in order.

Should also add an error for any duplicate column names explaining that they can add the replace keyword.

items.title: Table.bins column names should show max or min if outside start or end
items.body: Right now, if `start` or `end` are specified, `Table.bins` will include rows outside those values in the first or last bin. Problem is that the column names do not show that since the first bin will be called "[start - xxx]" instead of "[min - xxx]". This also causes `print_bars` to print an incorrectly labeled histogram from Table.bins.

items.title: Parse negative dollar amounts as number, not text
items.body: If a cell has "$1,287" it is parsed as a number, but if it has "-$1,287" it is parsed as text. Trying to force it to parse as a number throws the following: CastError: Can not parse value "-$1,287" as Decimal.

items.title: Eliminate the monkey-patching pattern for extensions
items.body: This can now be much more simply accomplished be replicating the way individual table methods have been separated into modules.

items.title: CastError should specify the row and column where the error occurred
items.body: I have some [data with tons of columns](https://github.com/lexieheinle/jour407homework/blob/master/StormData/nebraska-storm-analysis.ipynb), and I need to override several columns due to cast errors. However, it's difficult to narrow down which column is producing the data type error. Is it possible to print out the column name in addition to giving which value is producing the cast error?

items.title: Cookbook: removing a column (`select` and `exclude`)
items.body:
There doesn't appear to be any documentation on the best way to delete a column. Would seem to belong [here](http://agate.readthedocs.org/en/1.3.1/cookbook/columns.html) where the docs discuss reordering and renaming columns.

Right now I am using select to create a new table with the other columns selected, but this doesn't seem like the most efficient way.

items.title: Cookbook: overriding specific column types
items.body: Is it possible to override the type inference on multiple columns with the [TypeTester](http://agate.readthedocs.org/en/1.3.1/cookbook/create.html#from-a-csv)? Just tried it and couldn't figure it out. Workaround is to manually specify columns, but in a situation where the file has many columns and two need to be specified, this isn't user friendly. If it is possible, would make a good addition to the documentation.

items.title: Table.print_table should have default values for max_rows and max_columns
items.body: It shouldn't be possible to accidentally blow up your console. Smart defaults and then allow overriding to None.

items.title: Extension: agate-feather
items.body: Just read this. Curious if it could fit in with agate somehow. http://blog.rstudio.org/2016/03/29/feather/

items.title: `TableSet.having`
items.body:
Real world use case! Need a way to filter the TableSet's themselves. Example:

```
table = agate.Table.from_csv('data.csv')
grouped = table.group_by('thing')
big_groups = grouped.having(count of rows greater than 5)
```

Note, you can't use `where` because that's a proxy method.

Not sure the best way to implement this since you would want to be able to include an aggregation in the predicate...

items.title: MemoryError when I open a 300MB file
items.body:
Hey,

I'm getting a `MemoryError` when I open a file of about 300 MB, even if I set the `sniff_limit` to low number like this.

``` python
Table.from_csv("./my_big_file.csv", sniff_limit=1)
```

Am I doing something wrong, or is this just a limitation of agate?

items.title: It would be cool if we could open a fixed-width file using an ffs style config
items.body:
Maybe something like this

``` python
Table.from_csv(fixed_path, fixed_width_format="./myconfig.csv")
```

Though that kwarg is kind of weird. Maybe something like this would be better?

``` python
Table.from_fixed_width(fixed_path, format="./myconfig.csv")
```

Or maybe something totally different. But something that solved this would be great.

items.title: What if forked Tables had a param that pointed to their parent?
items.body:
Random thought I had recently. `Table`s could have a `parent` param that pointed to the `Table` they forked from or `None` if it was a top-level table.

Ideally, top-level `Table`s would hold original untouched data and each child `Table` would be a different piece of analysis branched from it. We'd then be able to implement methods to display where a `Table` came from and how it goes back to the original data. This may slightly address the problem @livlab brought up in #573 and contribute to agate's focus on reproducibility. 

Not sure if this is worth implementing or if it steps on [proof's](https://github.com/wireservice/proof) feet. Wanted to note it down just in case.

items.title: Skip rows on from_csv
items.body:
It would be cool if there was either a boolean parameter that allowed lines to be skipped in a csv when a table was loaded (could default to false) or a number of lines to skip (could default to zero). Lots of gov files have notes at the top before the real data start. 

For example, first 7 lines of Clinton's FEC contributor file: 

``` fec.gov
"title","Two Year Summary"
"description",2016""
"timestamp",24-FEB-16
"copyright","Copyright 2012, Federal Election Commission."
"cmte_id",P00003392
"cmte_nm","CLINTON, HILLARY RODHAM"
```

Trying to load this csv into a table currently throws the following error: 

`ValueError: Row 0 has 2 values, but Table only has 1 columns.`

items.title: It would be cool if I didn't have to use TypeTester to override one or two column types
items.body:
Today I'm working with a CSV with a dozen columns. Ten of them import fine automatically, but two need an override so the data types come out correct. To fix the problem I've done something like this:

``` python
tester = agate.TypeTester(force={
    'column_one': agate.Text(),
    'column_two': agate.Number(),
})
table = agate.Table.from_csv(csv_path, column_types=tester)
```

This is all fine and dandy. It works well. I can't complain too much.

However, the `TypeTester` code is a bit verbose with that nested dictionary. I doubt I'll ever be able to memorize that, and I suspect it might be tough for Python newbies to follow.

Would it be ridiculous to image something a little bit simpler like this?

``` python
column_types = {
    'column_one': agate.Text(),
    'column_two': agate.Number(),
}
table = agate.Table.from_csv(csv_path, column_types=column_types)
```

items.title: Can I group_by more than one column?
items.body:
``` python
table.group_by('column_one', 'column_two').aggregate([
    ('trump', agate.Sum('column_three')),
    ('total', agate.Sum('column_four')),
]).print_table()
```

It did not work. It only grouped by the first column. 

I would like to be able to do this.

items.title: Abstract print_structure method more cleanly
items.body: Super weird to have TableSet calling a Table "method"

items.title: MaxLength aggregation should return a Decimal
Fix (re-print) misaligned Tables in tutorial
items.body: Via @livlab: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1dVG876aVZoDxW5RyWBM7kC1ZTyPTrWqKBJctLuAh7gs/edit?ts=56e71c0e

items.title: Better error message when trying to call a disallowed Table method on a TableSet
Exonerations data in tutorial has weird states, e.g. `F-TX`
items.body:
Cleaning this up should be part of the analysis.

Via @livlab: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1dVG876aVZoDxW5RyWBM7kC1ZTyPTrWqKBJctLuAh7gs/edit?ts=56e71c0e

items.title: DateTime string inferred as Date
items.body:
A string which appears to be a valid datetime may be inferred as a date instead, chopping off the time.

```
 >>> tt = agate.data_types.TypeTester()
 >>> type(tt.run([ ("2015-01-01 02:34",) ], ("date",))[0])
 <class 'agate.data_types.date.Date'>
```

But forcing the type to DateTime parses it fine.

```
>>> tt = agate.data_types.TypeTester(force={ 'date': agate.DateTime() })
>>> type(tt.run([ ("2015-01-01 02:34",) ], ("date",))[0])
<class 'agate.data_types.date_time.DateTime'>
```

Date() is preferred to DateTime() in TypeTester.  In Date(), self.parser.parseDT parses as a datetime and returns status==3, which is not accepted.  isodate.parse_date is then used to parse the string, which succeeds, but chops off the time (as it encounters a space instead of `T`).  It seems that the permissive ISO date parsing is the issue here.

```
>>> isodate.parse_date("2015-01-01 02:34")
datetime.date(2015, 1, 1)
>>> isodate.parse_datetime("2015-01-01 02:34")
isodate.isoerror.ISO8601Error: ISO 8601 time designator 'T' missing. Unable to parse datetime string '2015-01-01 02:34'
```

Workaround is to force DateTime() type, or set an explicit date format.

items.title: Move TypeTester out of agate/data_types/__init__.py and into it's own module
items.body: `agate/type_tester.py`

items.title: Finish splitting table and tableset methods into separate modules
Move computations into their own modules
items.body: To match aggregations

items.title: Tidy up one-sentence aggregation descriptions so they fit in summary table.
Py2 and Py3 CSV readers/writers should have a common superclass
items.body: So only one set of classes will need to be imported/documented

items.title: Can csv._py2 be modified to so file-like inputs do not have to be re-encoded
items.body:
In `Table.from_csv`, this should not be necessary:

```
if six.PY2:
    contents = contents.encode('utf-8')
```

items.title: Table.from_csv is ignoring `encoding` argument
items.body: Because of sniffing implementation

items.title: Cookbook: CPI deflation
items.body: Use agate-lookup

items.title: Is there a way to create a table from a list of dictionaries?
items.body:
It's a pretty common use case in our parts to want to analyze data in memory that is a list of dictionaries. Is there a way for agate to slurp this up? And if not, can we figure out a way to add it?

Here's what happens now.

``` python
import agate

data = [
    dict(column_one='a', column_two=1),
    dict(column_one='b', column_two=2),
]

table = agate.Table(data)
table.print_table()

RuntimeWarning: Column names not specified. "('a', 'b')" will be used as names.
  table = agate.Table(data)
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "scratch.py", line 8, in <module>
    table = agate.Table(data)
  File "/home/ben/Code/agate/agate/table.py", line 157, in __init__
    self._column_types = column_types.run(rows, self._column_names)
  File "/home/ben/Code/agate/agate/data_types/__init__.py", line 93, in run
    if len(row) > i and not column_type.test(row[i]):
KeyError: 0
```

items.title: Encoding issue with test.csv when printing table on Windows 7 w/ vanilla Py2.7
items.body:
agate 1.3.0 w/ `examples/test.csv`

![ie11 - win7](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/33046/13605821/fdc1ed90-e50e-11e5-84a8-d71f611db1b4.png)

@mattwaite you seen this?

Do we need to be specifying in the docs that windows folks need to set their terminal to unicode OR [detecting the CLI encoding](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/6344853/python-unicode-in-windows-terminal-encoding-used) and outputting that?

items.title: Would column headers generated by the pivot be better and more descriptive if they included the computation type?
